questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption

    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with a history of bowel resection for Crohn's disease develops megaloblastic anaemia. Which component of the vitamin B12 metabolism is likely to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ileal resection for Crohn's disease can cause megaloblastic anaemia due to the decrease in cubilin receptors. They are the vitamin B12 receptors on the ileum.

Absorption of vitamin B12 involves the following steps:

  • Pepsin in the stomach releases vitamin B12 from the binding proteins in the food
  • Released B12 binds to haptocorrin, which is a salivary protein
  • In the duodenum, pancreatic proteases release B12 from haptocorrin
  • B12 binds to intrinsic factor to form IF-B12 complex
  • In the ileum, ileal enterocytes that contain cubulin receptors (IF receptor) endocytose the complex
  • In the ileal cells, B12 is associated with transcobalamin II, which is a carrier protein
  • B12 is delivered to the liver, bone marrow and GIT

questions.text: In which of the following patients would you not suspect megaloblastic anaemia caused by vitamin B12 deficiency?

choices.text: A 5-year-old child with fish tapeworm infestation

questions.solution:
Phenytoin therapy causes folate deficiency leading to megaloblastic anaemia. It does not cause vitamin B12 deficiency.

Dietary folate is in polyglutamate form, which is then converted into monoglutamates by the intestinal conjugase. Phenytoin acts by inhibiting this enzyme, thereby causing folate deficiency, and thus megaloblastic anaemia.

Options A, B and C: They cause megaloblastic anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiciency.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female with easy fatiguability and pallor presented to the OPD. The image of her hand is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Skin hyperpigmentation especially on the dorsum of hands involving the knuckles is seen in cyanocobalamin or vitamin B12 deficiency which is a causative factor of megaloblastic anaemia.

In megaloblastic anaemia, there is impairment of DNA synthesis that leads to ineffective hematopoiesis. It also causes distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

Clinical features of megaloblastic anaemia (cyanocobalamin and folate deficiency) include:

System Clinical features
Oral

Glossitis

Angular cheilosis
Gastrointestinal

Anorexia

Weight loss

Diarrhea

Constipation
Skin Hyperpigmentation (reversible)
Hematological

Thrombocytopenia

Leucopenia

Ineffective erythropoiesis and unconjugated jaundice
Cardiovascular

Atherosclerosis leading to PVD, CAD (due to elevated homocysteine)
Neurological (only B12)

Peripheral neuropathy

Subacute combined degeneration (degeneration of the posterior and pyramidal tracts of the spinal cord)
Pregnancy (only folate)

Recurrent fetal loss

Neural tube defects
Others

Mild fever in severe cases

Psychiatric disturbances

Peripheral smear findings:

  • Macro-ovalocytes
  • Most macrocytes lack the central pallor of normal red cells and even appear hyperchromic, but the MCHC is not elevated.
  • Reticulocyte count is low
  • Nucleated red cell progenitors occasionally appear in the circulating blood when anaemia is severe
  • Neutrophils are also larger than normal (macro polymorphonuclear) and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules

The image given below shows hypersegmented neutrophils seen in megaloblastic anaemia.

Bone marrow findings:

  • Markedly hypercellular as a result of increased hematopoietic precursors.
  • Sieve-like pattern of chromatin of immature precursors (Megaloblasts)
  • Granulocytic precursors also display dysmaturation in the form of giant metamyelocytes and band forms
  • Megakaryocytes can be abnormally large and have bizarre, multilobate nuclei
  • The derangement in DNA synthesis causes most precursors to undergo apoptosis in the marrow (ineffective hematopoiesis) and leads to pancytopenia

questions.text: Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in patients with megaloblastic anaemia?
questions.solution:
The reticulocyte count is decreased in megaloblastic anaemia.

The reticulocyte count is indicative of bone marrow function and its ability to produce healthy erythrocytes. In megaloblastic anemia, there is intramedullary hemolysis leading to raised indirect bilirubin and impaired erythroid maturation leading to a low reticulocyte count.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have megaloblastic anaemia. Which of the following will not be helpful in differentiating vitamin B12 deficiency from folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Increased serum homocysteine levels are common to both vitamin B12 deficiency and folate deficiency. Hence, it cannot be used to differentiate between them.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anaemia and see the following finding. Name the finding and its pathogenesis.

choices.text: Howell Jolly body - ineffective RBC enucleation

questions.solution:
The marked structure in this peripheral smear showing figure of 8 appearance is a Cabot ring. They are RBC inclusion bodies seen in conditions due to ineffective erythropoiesis. It is considered a remnant of microtubules during cell division.

Cabot rings can be seen in the following conditions:

  • Megaloblastic anaemia
  • Post-splenectomy patients
  • Lead poisoning
  • Hemolytic anemias 

Option A: Heinz bodies are due to oxidative damage, seen in G6PD deficiency.

Option B: Basophilic stippling is due to ribosomal precipitation, seen in heavy metal poisoning, thalassemia and sickle cell disease.

Option D: Howell Jolly bodies are due to ineffective RBC enucleation, characteristic of asplenia.

questions.text: Schilling's test can be used for all the following except _____

choices.text: To differentiate between vitamin B12 and folate deficiency
To identify the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency
To identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia

questions.solution:
Schilling test cannot identify the extent of megaloblastic anaemia.

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the antibodies of pernicious anaemia?

choices.text: Type I antibodies are found in both plasma and gastric juice
Type I antibody blocks the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor
Type II antibodies prevent the binding of the IF-B12 complex to ileal receptors
Type III antibodies are against haptocorrin

questions.solution:
Type III antibodies are not against haptocorrin. They recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pumps.

Pernicious anaemia is a specific form of megaloblastic anaemia caused by autoimmune gastritis. It impairs the production of intrinsic factor, which is required for vitamin B12 uptake from the gut. 

Types of antibodies in pernicious anaemia are:

  • Type I antibodies - block the binding of vitamin B12 to intrinsic factor. They are found in both plasma and gastric juice
  • Type II antibodies - prevent binding of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 (IF-B12) complex to its ileal receptor
  • Type III antibodies - recognize the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump of parietal cells

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents with complaints of light-headedness every time she stands up. She is a known case of rheumatoid arthritis on methotrexate. On examination, she has pallor and brittle nails. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: Serum iron and tissue iron levels are normal
Anemia can be normocytic and normochromic

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of anaemia of chronic diseases (ACD). In this condition, the anaemia initially can be normocytic normochromic.

ACD occurs in the setting of persistent systemic inflammation. It is associated with 

  • Low serum iron
  • Reduced total iron-binding capacity
  • Abundant stored iron in tissue macrophages

Inflammatory mediators like IL-6 stimulate an increase in the production of hepcidin. This inhibits ferroportin function in the macrophages and reduces the transfer of iron from the storage pool to developing erythroid precursors in the marrow. As a result, erythroid precursors are starved for iron despite the availability of plenty of iron in tissue macrophages.

questions.text: Identify the cell in the given peripheral blood smear and the likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Acanthocyte in anemia of renal disease
Acanthocyte in anemia of liver disease
Echinocyte in anemia of renal disease
Echinocyte in anemia of liver disease

questions.solution:
Acanthocyte or spur cells are seen in anaemia of liver disease. These cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying sizes that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals.

Conditions where acanthocytes can be seen include:

  • Severe liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy
  • Hyposplenism

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with acanthoctye.

Echinocytes or burr cells are seen in anaemia of renal disease. These cells are characterized by smaller, regularly spaced projections, smoothly rounded crenulations which are uniform in shape and distribution compared to acanthocytes.

Conditions where echinocytes can be seen include:

  • Anaemia of renal disease (uremia)
  • In premature infants, after exchange transfusion
  • Storage artefact

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with echinocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of aplastic anemia?
questions.solution:
From the given options, the most common cause of aplastic anemia is drugs. 

Causes of aplastic anemia:

Acquired 

  • Idiopathic - most common cause (about 65% of the cases)
  • Acquired stem-cell defects 
  • Immune-mediated

Chemical agents 

  • Dose-related
    • Alkylating agents
    • Antimetabolites
    • Benzene
    • Chloramphenicol
    • Inorganic arsenals
  • Idiosyncratic
    • Chloramphenicol
    • Phenylbutazone
    • Organic arsenicals
    • Carbamazepine
    • Penicillamine
    • Gold salts

Physical agents 

  • Whole-body irradiation
  • Viral infections - Hepatitis, CMV, EBV, VZ

Inherited 

  • Fanconi anemia 
  • Telomerase defects

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with progressive weakness and fatigue. Her hemogram is given below. What is the best investigation to arrive at the diagnosis?

Hb - 6 g%

RBC - 4 million/μL

WBC - 1000 /mm3

Platelets - 6500 /mm3
questions.solution:
The given hemogram is suggestive of pancytopenia. Cause of pancytopenia can be aplastic anaemia (hypocellular bone marrow) or myeloid neoplasms (hypercellular bone marrow). Hence, the best investigation is bone marrow biopsy to differentiate between them.

Findings in bone marrow biopsy in aplastic anaemia: 

  • Markedly hypocellular bone marrow largely devoid of hematopoietic cells 
  • Abundant fat cells 
  • Fibrous stroma, scattered lymphocytes, and plasma cells 

Bone marrow aspiration often yields a dry tap, so biopsy is preferred.

questions.text: Bone marrow biopsy of a patient with pancytopenia is given below. What is the most common infectious cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given bone marrow biopsy shows a hypocellular bone marrow with abundant fat cells which is suggestive of aplastic anaemia. In this condition, the most common infectious cause is viral hepatitis of the non-A, Non-B, Non-C, and Non-G type. 

The images given below show the normal and hypocellular bone marrow.

Note- Viral hepatitis, parvovirus B19, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), cytomegalovirus and Epstein-Barr virus can cause aplastic anemia. Viral hepatitis is however the most common cause.

questions.text:
Which of the following is likely to develop in a patient with aplastic anaemia?
  1. AML
  2. ALL
  3. CML
  4. CLL
  5. MDS
questions.solution: Aplastic anaemia can transform into both acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

questions.text:
Which of the following causes pure red cell aplasia?
  1. Parvovirus infection
  2. Thymoma
  3. Chronic neutrophilic leukemia
  4. Diamond Blackfan Syndrome
  5. Rifampicin use
questions.solution:
Causes of pure red cell aplasia include:

  • Neoplasms - thymomas and large granular lymphocytic leukemia
  • Drug exposure - phenytoin, azathioprine and isoniazid
  • Auto-immune disorders - neutralizing antibodies against erythropoietin
  • Parvovirus infection
  • Hereditary - Diamond Blackfan syndrome

questions.text: What is the most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of myelophthisic anaemia is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate. 

Myelophthisic anaemia describes a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. Causes include:

  • Metastatic cancer
  • Granulomatous diseases
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasms. 

This leads to the release of nucleated erythroid precursors and immature granulocytic forms into peripheral blood (leukoerythroblastosis) and tear-drop shaped red cells. 

The image given below shows a peripheral smear with teardrop cells.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with progressive weakness and chronic fatigue. Physical examination reveals a hard nodule of about 1cm in the prostate. His lab reports reveal low Hb and elevated PSA. Peripheral blood smear shows a normocytic normochromic picture. There are some occasional myelocytes, a few tear-drop cells and 2 nucleated RBCs per 100 white cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of myelophthisic anaemia. Prostatic mass with elevated PSA and age suggestive of prostatic carcinoma, which could be the likely cause in this case.

It is a form of marrow failure in which space-occupying lesions replace normal marrow elements. The most common cause is metastatic cancer from the breast, lung, and prostate.

Lab findings of myelophthisic anaemia include:

  • Myelocytes + nucleated RBCs = leukoerythroblastic image
  • Presence of tear-drop cells

questions.text: A 52-year-old male patient comes with complaints of abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. A peripheral blood smear reveals macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils and an endoscopy reveals atrophic gastritis. Which of the following conditions is likely to be seen this patient?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pernicious anemia, which is associated with atrophic gastritis and vitamin B12 deficiency.

Anemic patient with a peripheral smear showing macrocytic RBCs and hypersegmented neutrophils are important characteristic features of megaloblastic anemia. Vitamin B12 and folic acid deficiency are the main causes of megaloblastic anemia.

Pernicious anemia is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of autoantibodies which impairs the production or activity of the intrinsic factor (IF). This is required for the uptake of vitamin B12. There are three types of autoantibodies namely, type I, II, and III. The action of each of these include:

  • Autoantibody type I prevents the binding of vitamin B12 to the intinsic factor (IF).
  • Autoantibody type II prevents the binding of vitamin B12-IF complex to the ileal receptors.
  • Autoantibody type III acts against the α and β subunits of the gastric proton pump, which impairs the production of intrinsic factor.

These patients also develop chronic atrophic gastritis, characterized by loss of parietal cells, infiltration of lymphocytes and plasma cells and megaloblastic changes in mucosal cells.
